III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation When youth was in the independent living home the case worker
spoke inappropriate to the youth, was racist against him and told
him to go back to his country. Additionally, the worker/agency did
not ensure he had food.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A resided in a Holy Cross Independent Living home, but his
foster care case management was provided by Bethany Christian
Services.
Complainant
On 4/28/2025 I spoke with Complainant via a translator,
Interpreter who spoke Arabic. Complainant reported information,
as reported by Youth A. It is noteworthy initially it was unclear this
complaint was to be assigned to Bethany but complainant confirm
the complaint was against Bethany.
Youth A
On 4/28/2025 I interviewed Youth A via the assistance of
Interpreter who spoke Arabic. Youth A reported he and other
youths were living in an independent living (IL)organization
through Holy Cross and the IL placement only took him one time
to get food. He said staff at the IL placement verbally threatened
him, and other boys, which they had a recording of, but nothing
physical happened to him. He said the staff at the IL placement
were treating him different than the American youth; and that was
racism. The example Youth A gave for the different treatment was
that once he and boys from other countries cooked food, the Holy
Cross staff threw their food out. Youth A reported Foster Care
Worker 1 (FCW 1) and Foster Care Supervisor 1(FCS 1) knew
what was going on at the IL placement and they did not do
anything about their mistreatment. Youth A said they asked FCW
1 and FCS 1 to go to another home and they said, “no”. He said
they ran out of food at the house, and he asked FCW 1 and
2

Bethany for food, and they did not bring food. He reported he and
his friends were out begging for food. He reported FCS 1 told him
he had one choice to stay in the placement or Bethany would
present the paperwork to court to send him back to his country.
He reported he was in that placement two months and nothing
was done for him. He said FCW 1, and FCS 2 threatened to send
him back to his country when he complained about things.
On one hand Youth A reported not getting monies for his needs
while he was in the IL placement and not having food; then on the
other hand, he admitted to getting a onetime payment of $
1,600.00 from a special fund, then a $800.00 monthly stipend from
another source. He also acknowledged Bethany made
arrangements for him to get those funds. He reported the monies
he had to buy his food was not enough and when he would
complain about the way he was threatened with being sent back
to his country. Youth A did not recall a person/consultant like me
or any other departmental person investigating concerns of him
and other boys not having food, being threatened or them not
receiving funds for their care while he/they lived in the Holy Cross
IL placement under Bethany. It is worth noting those allegations
were investigated via Special Investigation 2025SIC0000298.
Youth A reported being in a foster home placement now; and
having a different worker than FCW 1. He reported the $800.00
monthly fund now goes to his foster parent instead of him. He
reported feeling he is also treated differently in the foster home
than the other children. The example he gave as proof of the
different treatment is that the foster father drives the other children
to school regularly and not him. He denied the foster father
threatening him or verbally or physically harming him. He denied
FCW 1 or FCS1 ever verbally or physically threatening or
maltreating him. He reported feeling Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW
2), who is his current worker, is not listening to him, his concerns
and has insulted him. He reported two weeks prior to this
interview he asked FCW 2 to allow him to go to regular school
instead of the adult school he attends, and she indicated he could
not. FCW 2 told him he needs to go to this current school and if
he continues to complain, Bethany will go back to court and tell
the court he is complaining so he is sent back to his country. He
reported he is not trying to complain; he is trying to be heard. He
also reported two weeks ago when he and a friend asked the
worker to stay and talk, they said he held the worker hostage,
would not let her leave. Youth A indicated that was not true and he
believed that is the kind of things the agency uses to threaten him.
3

Youth A reported he just wants to feel comfortable here, to go to
the school he wants, and get medical care, and vaccines.
Chief Administrator (CA)
On 4/29/2025 I had email correspondences with CA related to the
complaint. She affirmed Youth A’s placement via Bethany, with
him currently being in a treatment foster home. She reported
being aware of the allegations and indicated Youth A has made
complaint multiple times. She reported the complaints have been
investigated and not found to be substantiated. She also reported
Youth A has called the police, children protective service and the
FBI multiple times stating these same allegations. CA reported the
agency has a meeting with Youth A this afternoon to discuss
concerns; and the agency has had multiple conversations with
Youth A in the past about concerns and trying to work through
things. CA reported it appears when Youth A does not receive an
answer that suits him, including a lack of willingness from the
foster parent to purchase him a gym membership, he claims
racism and other false allegations. CA reported they continue to
try to work with him to meet his needs and support the placement.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 (FCS 1)
On 4/30/2025, I interviewed FCS 1 by telephone. She reported
she was the supervisor assigned to Youth A case prior to him
going to a foster home; and FCW 1 was his assigned worker. She
explained when Youth A arrived in Michigan he was placed in a
foster home temporally for five days. Thereafter, he went to Holy
Cross’s IL-Plus group home, but she and FCW 1 remained the
assigned supervisor and worker.
FCS 1 reported Youth A was always provided his stipend. She
reported Youth A received a stipend twice monthly. He received
$825.00 monthly, and it was to pay for rent and pay for groceries.
She reported Youth A often refused to engage in services at Holy
Cross’s IL group home, but he always received his stipend. Holy
Cross provided Bethany memo’s showing Youth A received his
checks. She reported the name of two Holy Cross staff who could
verify this. She acknowledged Youth A, Youth B and other boys in
the refugee program had often made complaints of not having
food. She said there were at least two investigations, by Michigan
Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) and the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL). She reported the
boys had called MDHHS and the police at least twice complaining
of that; but Youth A and the other boys were provided funds to buy
food. Bethany also provided the boys with gift cards weekly to
purchase food, the IL staff took the boys to food pantries twice
4

weekly; and there were food banks. FCS1 reported Youth A was
encouraged to spend his stipend in responsible ways, but Youth A
did not do that. She said sometimes he would spend all his money
in a day, buying SIM cards, a television and once a cell phone.
FCS 1 denied ever telling Youth A to go back to his country; or
being aware of FCW 1 or Holy Cross IL staff doing so. She
reported not knowing why that would be stated because going
back to his country is not even an option for him. She reported
she and FCW 1 never disrespected Youth A or his culture. She
reported Youth A, Youth B and a couple of other boys would claim
discrimination or racism if they were told they had to wait for
things, like it would take two weeks for their checks to start. She
reiterated that all the allegations by Youth A were previously
investigated, inclusive of an allegation against an IL staff. She
reported with regards to the allegation against an IL staff, it was
alleged by the IL youths that a staff threw away their food, told
them they are refugees and did not deserve food, and threatened
them while a knife was on the table. FCS 1 reported the boys
concern about that matter were not ignored, Bethany contacted
MDHHS about that matter, it was investigated (2025SIC0000382),
Holy Cross IL terminated that staff, and Bethany replaced Youth
A, Youth B and Bethany’s other youths from the IL home based on
the allegations.
Foster Care Worker 1 (FCW 1):
On 5/5/2025, I interviewed FCW 1 by telephone. FCW 1 was the
worker for Youth A from 12/18/2024 until 2/19/2025. She affirmed
information as reported by FCS 1 pertaining to Youth A’s stipend.
Additionally, she affirmed how Youth A might have spent his
funds, him having a $1600.00 overseas account, and his past
complaints about not having food and funds. She confirmed what
the IL home and Bethany did related to ensuring that the youths in
the IL home had food. She also reported those complaints were
previously investigated by DCWL and MDHHS. FCW 1 denied any
awareness of Youth A and his friends going out and begging for
food. She further reported the IL house staff took the children
grocery shopping weekly and there were also food trucks that
visited the home. She admitted it initially took until approximately
1/27/2025 to get Youth A’s stipend open. But even after Youth A
was getting his $800.00 monthly stipend, he complained about
food. She reported Holy Cross and Bethany provided him and
other youths gift cards via Walmart and Meijer, etc.
FCW 1 denied discriminating against Youth A or telling him to go
back to his country. She reported Youth A was either making this
5

up or misunderstood something he heard. She reported during a
time when speaking on the phone with him, via an interpreter she
was explaining to him that he needed to sign his IL contract and
that he would need to be in compliance with the contract. She
reported Youth A was refusing to get a medical and the health
care would have been included in his contract. She said during the
call she advised Youth A that if he was not incompliance with the
contract, he ran the risk of being sent back to his country. She
never told him he would be sent back, nor threatened to send him
back to his country.
FCW 1 also reported during her contact to the IL house, which
initially were weekly then every other week, she never observed
any discrimination against Youth A, or any of the youths. She said
Youth A shared the IL home with three other youths from Sudan;
along with other youths who were primarily African American. She
never observed the other children or the staff mistreating Youth A.
FCW 1 reported when Youth A was assigned to her, due to it
being around Christmas time, Youth A only attended school a
couple of days. He then had to be quarantine; and after he was
replaced she was not aware of any concerns he may have with
school or concerns related his foster home.
Independent Living House Program Manager (ILHPM)
On 5/9/2025 I interviewed Holy Cross’ Independent Living House
Program Manager (ILHPM) by telephone. ILHPM confirmed
information reported by FCW 1 and FCS 1 pertaining to stipends
for Youth A and Youth B. He also affirmed information related
Youth A, and Youth B running out of food due to them spending all
their money; and what Holy Cross and Bethany did by way of gift
cards; and food trucks; and that both boys were never without
food. He said, the IL home even reached out to an Islamic refugee
outreach which had Mideastern food, so the boys might have food
of their culture. He said other boys in the home also shared food
with them. He reported both Youth A and Youth B received
stipend payments of $385 every two weeks; and Holy Cross tried
to help them set of bank accounts. He said he provided Bethany
proof of the stipends. He said Bethany also assisted the boys in
obtaining $600 or more from an initial account that was available
to the boys so that the boys could purchase things. He reported
the boys would complain about different things and even called
the FBI on Holy Cross alleging they were not providing them
services.
6

ILHPM reported FCW 1, and FCS 1 made sure Youth A, Youth B
and the other boys received services, but for some reason the
boys didn’t fully understand the IL placement. They seemed to
think they were in prison. ILHHPM denied ever witnessing FCW 1
or FCS 1 talking negatively to the boys, calling them out their
names nor disrespecting them or behaving in a racist manner
towards them.
Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW 2)
On 5/19/2025 I interviewed FCW 2 by telephone. FCW 2 has been
Youth A’s case worker since 2/19/2025, when he was placed in a
treatment foster home. FCW 2 reported Youth A has made
several complaints, and she has met with him to discuss his
complaints. She has talked with him and the foster father on more
than one occasion to try to better understand concerns and what
is going on related to Youth A’s feelings and the complaints. She
affirmed CA’s reporting of the agency meeting with Youth A on
4/29/2025. She reported they were aided by an interpreter. Youth
A was frustrated and continued to claim racism and was unable to
give the agency specifics as to what he wants or give legitimate
examples of discrimination. She also denied ever telling Youth A
she would send him back to his country or to disrespect or
discriminate again him nor had she witnessed any other staff
doing such. She said Youth A appears to want to return to Grand
Rapids to be with his friends.
FCW 2 reported Youth A is placed in a foster home with two other
youths and his foster father provides good care to him. She
reported when Youth A was first placed in the foster home he
complained about his overseas funds. There was about $300.00
left in that account, and they helped Youth A access those funds.
She was not sure what he spent the funds on. Youth A does not
get a stipend now, he gets an allowance. She reported she has
visited the foster home regularly and there is always food in the
home; and Youth A has been provided food of his culture. She
reported there have been no special evaluation warranted on the
foster home. She reported Youth A attends an adult education
school program. She helped him get into that educational setting
after he was in a regular school and complained about wanting to
go at a faster pace, so as to graduate sooner. He is doing well in
the program; has a tutor and is not struggling. FCW 2 reported
she and the foster father have also explained to Youth A why the
other foster children received a ride to school, their schools being
miles away and his three minutes away, which he rides his bike to
by his choice. The foster father originally gave all of the children
rides, due to the weather, but now that the weather is warmer,
7

Youth A can ride his bike. FCW 2 reported Youth A struggles in
his placement and that may be tied to culture and emotional
adjustment issues. The agency has pursued mental health service
for him; and they hope with therapy and other supportive
measures Youth A will feel more comfortable and supported.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 (FCS 2)
On 5/19/2025 I interview FCW 2 by telephone related to the
allegations. She denied the allegations and affirmed base
information as reported by FCW 2. She had no knowledge of
anyone telling Youth A to go back to his country.
She also reported the agency assisted Youth A in getting the
balance of about $600 from a refugee account that gets
established for youths like him when they enter the county. She
reported Youth A does still receive monies. He receives an
allowance as given by the foster parent. She added that when
she has meet with Youth A, he has reported wanting another
person to have his case due racism, but he has been unable to
give examples of the racism. She reported Youth A knows she is
the supervisor; and he has never reported FCW 2, or the foster
parent calling him out his name or disrespecting him in some
manner.
Youth B
On 5/30/2025 I interviewed Youth B by telephone with the aid of
Interpreter. Youth B reported being in the Holy Cross IL placement
with Youth A. He reported in that placement it was never about a
lack of food, (but the kitchen did close at 9:00pm); or him and
Youth A and other youths not knowing the rules. It was about the
mistreatment and “no respect”. He described the mistreatment
and no respect being that they were placed in a bad placement at
Holy Cross; and then moved to another bad placement. He
reported the placement was bad because he was not given his
money and when he complained they threatened to kick him out
the house. He reported FCS 2 threatened to kick him out the IL
house and then moved him. Youth B could not recall whether a
person like me had investigated his concerns in the past.
Youth B denied FCW 1 or FCW 2 verbally or physically harming
him, cursing or calling him out his name nor had he witnessed or
heard FCW 1 or FCS 1 doing such to Youth A or other youths.
Notwithstanding this, Youth B continued stating he needs help
getting what he wants, which he reported is to move to a better
placement.
8

Documents Reviewed:
Youth A MISACWIS record which showed:
• Youth A was an unaccompanied refugee from Sudan and
arrived in the United States on 12/18/2024 where he was
placement in a foster home until 12/23/2024.
• On 12/23/2024 he was placed in a Holy Cross’s
Independent Living-plus group home under Bethany
Refugee program’s supervision.
• Youth A is a temporary court ward.
• He was placed in his current foster home placement on
2/19/2025.
• He had a medical and dental examination on 1/30/2025.
• Service plans which showed Youth A’s medical and
immunization to be up to date; he had been taken for food,
clothing, medical care, and financial services were
completed for him.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000298, which showed:
• Youth B was the primary youth the allegations related to;
and all youths in the IL home, including Youth A, were
interviewed.
• The allegations were that FCW 1 was not providing the
youth with entitled funding, placed the youth in a shelter
and told him if he did not like it he can go back to his
country.
• Youth A during his interview reported he had not received
a last month’s check but understood the program was
working on getting the rest of the money. He reported
feeling safe and did not report any concerns about FCW 1
• No violations were established.
Copy of Stipend checks proof from ILHPM which showed:
• Youth A and Youth B received $ 385.84 two times per
month with $134.96 for rent; and $250.88 to the youth.
• The payments were paid out initially on 1/17/2025 for the
period 12/23/2024- 12/29/2025 in the amount of $192.92,
with $67.48 for rent and $125.05 to the youth. Then the full
amounts of $385.84 were paid out thereafter twice monthly.
The last payment via Holy Cross showed as dated
2/11/2025 for the period 1/27/2025- 2/9/2025.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence does
not support the allegations or that the staff lacked responsible
character suitable and able to meet the needs of children and
families served by the agency.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
